article:
The '[[military history|history]] of the [[United States Marine Corps]]' began
with the founding of the Continental Marines on 10 November 1775 to conduct ship-to-
ship fighting, provide shipboard security and discipline enforcement, and assist
in landing forces. Its mission evolved with changing military doctrine and
foreign policy of the United States. Owing to the availability of Marine forces
at sea, the United States Marine Corps has served in nearly every conflict in
United States history. It attained prominence when its theories and practice of
amphibious warfare proved prescient, and ultimately formed a cornerstone of the
Pacific Theater of World War II. By the early 20th century, the Marine Corps
would become one of the dominant theorists and practitioners of amphibious
warfare. Its ability to rapidly respond on short notice to expeditionary crises
has made and continues to make it an important tool for American foreign
policy.
categories: History of the United States Marine Corps|*
headings: Establishment of the modern Marine Corps
